Less care, yes. Less tests, no. Fewer tests. You prove the point. I'm sorry but that lack of basic grammar strikes me. I'm glad you're not a writer, given your error, but that does not speak to your skills as a physician. I'd rather have my QALYs based on the European vs American cost of a drug, but I want the person running the numbers to be an actual statistician, not an MD or sociologist.

BTW, I'm a big believer in the lab test versus the colonoscopy as I don't want the sedation and the cost differences for my insurance company and therefore society are revolting, given the efficacy of each. One simple example...

There's a dirty little secret in medicine - cost effectiveness is already being used - er, misused - to make real medical decisions about real patients every day. In residency training programs such as one I teach within, we are told to evaluate a residents knowledge of "cost effective" medicine. Yet these are young physicians, and like me, they have no training whatsoever in the health outcomes methodology necessary to make such decisions. In the wake of ACA, health systems across the country are putting pressure on individual physicians to perform "cost effective" medicine, which is a thinly veiled attempt to get them to provide less care and do less tests - without any system-wide analysis of the sort reasonably described here. Individual physicians must focus on only one thing - providing the best care possible to their patients, operating within a system (preferably single payer) in which society, in collaboration with the best science, determines the tests and procedures that are available. Individual doctors making individual "cost effective" decisions is a recipe for poor decisions and poorer medical care.

"Nursing Home" is much too broad a description for the variety of living arrangements available to people who are unable to live alone, wash or dress themselves or prepare meals.  More significant needs such as taking medicines as scheduled or using medical devices do require some skilled care. As many have noted in other columns about long-term care, the actual facility amenities are just part of what creates a nurturing environment for people to live in.  Management and staffing is a critical part of the success of any living arrangement.  Those of us who have overseen the care of relatives who entered luxurious "assisted living" homes with skilled marketing professionals promising the Good Life while aging in place, have learned our lessons.  We know to ask about staff turnover, specific management policies,  staff to resident ratios, privacy policies and other items not included in the glossy brochures.  I hope the Green House Movement is more than just a marketing strategy.  Warehousing our elderly until they die or they are no longer profitable is not a sustainable option for long term care.

I think Paul is addressing one of the challenges in implementing a noble concept  by Dr. Thomas and others who have identified common needs among most elderly people that until recently were ignored because of medical and social ignorance and insensitivity and the demands for institutional efficiency. Our very diverse backgrounds plus our physical and mental conditions as we age, limits how well needs can be met. One person's idyllic environment can be another's source of depression.

It's possible the industrial revolution changed elder care, but in fact it was the introduction of the aged pension that enabled old people to NOT live with their relatives.

This suggests no-one wants to live with their kids, the inlaws or the grandkids. The situation described as 'loving home care' is the fantasy of cultures that don't want the far more difficult task of supporting independence in old age, and letting the sick die.

Another model is the RCFE (in California, Residential Care Facility for the Elderly). They're licensed and inspected by the state, but run privately. They really are homes, with 24/7 assistance for the residents.

Let's start with the Sheridan Green House.

$290 a day. The"cottages" appear to be a single room with a hospital bed, the common area is achingly WalMart, everything on the website is typically institutional. From the outside, the "campus" looks forelorn and dreary. And forget a refrigerator. You can't have one. Eat what they give you.

This is another one of these "started out as a good intention" to push the Nursing Home Establishment to a different sensibility and standard.

But it won't happen.

Money and the American Way and busy self-promoting developers are really at work here. Yesterday it was called the "Eden Alternative"-- I saw that at work...nursing homes putting large bird cages in the hallways and dubbing it a miracle. The "inmates" were still lined up in wheelchairs.

In France, short of acute need for 24/7 medical care, the elderly stay at home, have cleaning assistance 2x a week with laundry done. All doctor appointments and church and social activities get you an escort, no questions asked. Regular nursing visits, etc. All included in their taxes. Thousands benefit...as does society.

This also happens in many other European countries.

Let's stop hopping onto the PR train whenever someone writes a new book with some fabulous concept.

In this country, it is all about money.

Thank you to for exposing Jewish Home Lifecare for what it is...a fraud.

This is a study of people who are “nonemployed,” which is defined differently from the usual measures of “unemployment.” An unemployed person is looking for work and can’t find it. In this study respondents are “nonemployed” if they ever worked full-time but are not working now.

An advantage of studying the “nonemployed” is that you include discouraged workers, those who are no longer looking and hence don’t meet the definition of “unemployed.” But on the downside you have the anomaly seen in this series, of lumping those who are deliberately home with their children into a category painted broadly as consisting of unfortunates, as people who need to be “gotten back to work,” even if they need to be “lured” there.

The write-up of the study linked to doesn’t give us the responses broken out by gender to which the authors seem to have access. But considering the male and female respondents together, 30% describe themselves as homemakers, 43% left work per their own decision, 40% are mostly happy with not working. All the data alluded to in the article indicate that those percentages would be substantially higher if we looked at the women alone.

What this study in fact highlights are the very reasons that influence women to stay home – because they find that leaving work improves their relationships, especially with their children. How is that not a legitimate motive? Could we please stop treating mothers at home as if they need to be fixed?
You remarks may indeed be accurate, but this article was not about the development you're referring to. Why choose to vent your disagreement here?
